summary:
not necessarily meant to be funny, just what i think will happen in thor four: 
thor: valkyrie! i would like you to meet my...
body:
not necessarily meant to be funny, just what i think will happen in thor four:

thor: valkyrie! i would like you to meet my single friend, who is a lesbian, carol.

valkyrie: thor, just because you meet a girl who likes girls doesn’t mean-

carol: hey

valkyrie:

valkyrie: thor?

thor: yeah?

valkyrie: she likes girls?

thor: yeah

valkyrie: give her my number.

thor: you are already set to go out on thursday.

valkyrie: this is why you’re the god of lesbians, isn’t it

thor: well i- wait, what do you mean god of lesbians?

summary: You know that train fight right? Where Carol fights the shape-shifter that looks like an old lady, where the bystanders keep...
body: You know that train fight right? Where Carol fights the shape-shifter that looks like an old lady, where the bystanders keep trying to protect the “old woman” even after all the crazy acrobatics start? I loved it. Because at first it’s just a scene where the ‘silly bystanders’ are making the heroes job harder. But then after we learn what we do, you realise it was a GOOD thing that they were trying to stop her. I love the twist of it.

reblog.comment: You know that train fight right? summary: Captain Marvel Commentary - Spoilers Ahead There are several lines from Yon-Rogg that caught my attention. I don’t have the...
body:
Captain Marvel Commentary - Spoilers Ahead

There are several lines from Yon-Rogg that caught my attention. I don’t have the exact quotes, but he twice says to Carol something along the lines of, “I want to make you into your best self.” He is insistent that “she has [his] blood running through her veins”. To succeed, he says she must repress her emotions. He tells her that he is the source of her power and that, “what has been given can be taken away”.

What Yon-Rogg is doing here is establishing control over Carol. He wants her to believe that he controls her power, that he made her who she is, that he knows what’s best for her, that she should be grateful. Not only is this behavior manipulative, it’s all a complete lie. Yon-Rogg didn’t give her powers; they are hers alone. He did not save her; he kidnapped her and planted false memories in her head. He did not train her to be a hero; she was one long before he found her. In training, he forces her to fight him without her powers, telling her it’s to teach her control, but really, it’s nothing more than a way to make sure he can beat her. As Carol herself puts it, the Kree held her to nigh-impossible standards while also holding one hand behind her back.

And - surprise surprise - these are some of the insidious ways that the system is geared toward discouraging women. Got a good job? Be grateful. Held to arbitrarily high expectations, even when the men around you aren’t? Toughen up. Want equal pay and/or maternity leave? Prove you’re worth it first. Make a fuss about unequal treatment? Stop being so overemotional. And remember, what you have can always be taken away again.

Except, through some soul-searching and rebuilding relationships with the women in her life, Carol exposes the lies Yon-Rogg fed her. She knows her power is her own. She knows that her worth is not determined by his opinion or by her place in his system. So when he tries to force her to prove herself by his standards, she is completely uninterested. She just says, “I have nothing to prove to you,” and that’s the end of it.

tags: Nick Fury was actually really great tho
summary: So I watched Nick Fury and his SuperFriends: Nick Fury gains First Friend Good movie. The female side character was quite boring...
body:
So I watched Nick Fury and his SuperFriends: Nick Fury gains First Friend

Good movie.

The female side character was quite boring tho. :^)
Mostly due to the fact the we aren’t actually shown the interesting parts of her story, which would be her past. We only get told how amazeballs she was, but all we see is how she was shit at go-kart and rope climbing. No cool piloting, no cool training with the Kree, no interaction with Mar Vell to show us why Carol respected her so much, no nuthin.

Also I like how the movie neither bothered to mention why there are non-blue Kree, nor where Mar Vell got the fucking Tesseract from.
